author: @BauthorFowler

text:
Relating to others who want to get into Metroid- I dont know the community consensus on Dread yet, but while its a solid place to start... Most are... Fusion or Zero Mission are often the 2D titles recommended first. Considering as its notably harder than prior titles Im not sure if Dread will supersede them, but if a game looks fun go ahead and start there. No ones stopping you, just Fusion and Zero Mission are often suggested because they are more friendly to newer players than the likes of Super. 

Fusion is more story driven and linear than Super, and Zero Mission is built off of Fusions solid back, making an equivalent to the first title thats far easier to get into, though its considered by far to be the easiest title in the series. 

Where you start will likely determine how you enjoy the series, and consider that each of them is trying to do something different. Matter of fact, what Super did none of the others tried after it. Each is a unique experience, and some will have strong preferences based on what they look for in a title. Dont be dissuaded based on the opinions of others. 

And if you decide to play Other M, keep in mind in English Samus took alot more abuse than her Japanese version did, who questioned the orders that lowered her survival chances until she just did things her way. The localization butchered her, and as such be wary of it for that reason. Its fine to enjoy it though, personal preference. Its arguably a black sheep of the series due to the localization and how it handles its controls, but that does mean its unlike any other.

author: @TheZero1312

text:
To be fair, gura hit the ceiling accidentally first while fighting, revealing one of the destructible blocks. Admittedly, that room stopped me for longer than most actual puzzles in the game, personally. With that said... The claims he made were wildly overblown. Yes, there was absolutely room for improvement with the map design, there, but it falls short of hurting the game itself and it is far from the most accessibility-antagonistic decision they made for the game. Like... The normal mode here is most metroidvania games' hard mode, and the final boss made me yearn for the halcyon days of fighting the emperor ing with friggin' tank controls.

It was fun for me, as an experienced player, to 100%, but I have several friends for whom I simply can't recommend the game. Not everyone has the time to fail until you can succeed. For everyone else? Well, that's what games are supposed to have hard modes for, yeah?
author: @psiah9889

text: ¬†@psiah9889¬† The room is designed so you "accidentally" shoot upwards.
author: @AlexaRobin21

text:
Nintendo has always had better game design than Sony. I like Sony's games, but sometimes it feels too much like it was made to be award bait with their visuals and stories. A lot of their games feel too much like walking simulators at points and have only good gameplay. Never "great" like Nintendo.

Meanwhile, Nintendo games are all about fun, always have, always will. They might not have the best stories or graphics, but what they do have is innovation. Sony tends to make run of the mill AAA games by comparison.

Though sometimes I do enjoy a good story, and that can be found in Sony games. It's really about your mood and tastes. I will say some JRPG stories are just as good if not better, they're just not noticed as much since they're not as award-baity.

text: ¬†@McCaroni_Sup¬† Definitely both "award" bait, as well as "virtue-signaling" bait.

author: @a_creatorsstuff17

text:
For the newbs, fast crash course.

Samus's parents were killed by Ridley and the Space Pirates while she was a child and she was adopted by the Chozo. They raised her to do battle. They are 10-foot birdmen. She knows their language, mythology and fighting style... they even spliced her DNA with theirs, and modded a suit of the first Human-Chozo battle armor for her.

As she hit her teens, Samus left her tribe to join the military, seeking revenge against the Space Pirate organization. Following a traumatic disaster in which she was ordered to do nothing while a friend died, Samus left her position in the Galactic Federation. She's been a bounty hunter ever since.

author: @exetone

text: It's possible to have a more nuanced view on Other M than "literally all of its plot is good" and "literally all of its plot is bad". If Samus was traumatized by being ordered to do nothing while a friend died, and that explains her stoic/silent behavior on missions, I honestly think that's pretty cool, but I really don't like a lot of the other plot bits of Other M.
author: @GarryDumblowski

text:
That's a pretty nice summary, but the last sentence referring to Other M could be considered non-canon as that game contradicts the lore of every single game that came before and after it, plus the manga it was based on.
(I know Dread acknowledges its existence, but it is kinda in passing with the extras after clearing the game).
author: @TwilightWolf032

text:
¬†@TwilightWolf032¬† it was in the official manga... Other M: took liberties, but is overall accurate... 

I got excited in the premier trailer when you heard "any objections, Lady?" That's because of Metroid Fuzion. Samus said in that game (the last story in the timeline) that she named her new ship's AI "Adam,"  after her CO in the Federation.

Really shows how different skills can result in a different experience. Anyway, great stream, great game. Love Metroid. Would love to see Gura play more of the series some day.

text: This game has such an annoying habit of abruptly blocking off huge sections of the map for no particular reason. I don't know where I'm supposed to go, so I don't know where I'm not supposed to go, so I end up accidentally going the way I am supposed to go, and then the game blocks off all of the optional areas that I didn't explore because I mistakenly went the right way. Just let me explore!
author: @ZeroSpawn47

text: Just a nitpick but I'd argue it was more gene therapy than vax
author: @ImprovmanZero

text: Honestly, it's pretty frustrating to watch these streams for that exact reason. I've always disliked how much streamers tend to rely on chat instead of figuring it out themselves. But it's not just the streamers fault, it's also the people enabling it by posting what to do in the chat lol. That being said, it's hard for me to deny that it's frustrating to watch her play and barely use half her abilities, only charge shoot, and never use missiles lol.
author: @LunarUmi

text: On the contrary, I've found this game to be the most challenging yet, and it seems most people are finding the same. What game would be more difficult than this one? Throughout the whole game, you're never that powerful, unlike past titles where once you get 3 energy tanks you're basically invincible.
author: @LunarUmi

text: ¬†@LunarUmi¬† like most speed runners do you can just run past the EMMIs all the time you dont have to hide. I found that out on the second EMMI that you can just run by them and it seems that's actually the intended strategy. If you noticed they seem to place health recharge stations after EMMI rooms almost as if they intended you to use your health tanks as a extender to your cloak. After about the 3rd or 4th health tank you always have enough health to stealth past even the under water EMMI rooms basically making them child's play at that point. I'll admit that unlike most people I was able to counter the EMMIs every time they caught me so I would use that when I had to kill them just blow their shield up let them touch me parry run behind charge and kill on first contact. Every EMMI can be killed as soon as you exit the control units room and they start the chase so that was not even a challenge their is enough room to break their shield and charge your cannon. The few bosses in the game where not hard at all with most if you had fast enough fingers could be phased skipped. I noticed that in the X that's attached to the magma reactor where I was able to get him to his final phase after the first party mechanic and I skipped most of the fight. Raven beak is also a easy final boss which I cleared without ever taking damage 3 times in a row because my switched over heated as soon as I broke the final door. You can phase skip raven beak as well with only needing 2 party attacks to send him into the next phase for each phase. His flight phase is annoying but the phase shifting skill samus gets makes it so you can, with fast fingers so I'll admit that one is abit hard for most people, to just jump around him and shift away to safety while constantly attacking him with missiles. To be fair the phase shifting skill is what makes him a breeze since you can always dash away and to him to safety as he always does the exact attacks back to back so dash away let him do is aoe so dash to him to safety and dash away as he will 100% of the time follow that up with a melee combo then jump over him and launch missiles and he will follow up with his dash attack you can parry. Do that 2 times and congratulations next phase without seeing any other mechanics. Final phase just don't move and shoot missiles and use phase shifting to dodge all of his attacks and congrats next phase. Final phase a power bomb will blow up the sun aoe but really you can screw attack around it while you dodge the laser and then land and shoot missiles which will cause him to do his dash attack again do that twice and you finished the fight.
author: @sanyaiase2165

text: ¬†@LunarUmi¬† I will say I found metroid fusion to be harder in general but it does make me think it's not that fusion is harder is just that Dread controls more smoothly. I do think a major part of why I feel the game is easier is just the fact that most of the challenges past metroid games had was a lack of proper "aiming" controls and dodging mechanics while these newer games give you massive amounts of ways to just stop a boss in its tracks and punish the hell out of them. Also samus just moves like butter in dread which makes it easy to doge enemies as well. It might just be the fluid controls that makes the game easy to me.
author: @sanyaiase2165

author: @TR-vp7en

text:
Yea, I've only ever played the original Metroid for NES and Super Metroid for the SNES, but I can already tell that this will be one of my favorite Metroid games ever. Samus moves and flows so fluidly, and you start off with 6 different moves! That's 5 more than the original! Granted, as I said, I haven't played Fusion, which many say is the best in the 2D series, but I digress. I also love the spine-chilling EMMI and the mysterious Chozo villian (no spoilers please! I've only defeated 2 EMMI), the whole atmosphere really lives up to the name: Dread. OK I'm done ranting now :)
Oh yea Gura, keep going! <3

text: ¬†@drowningin¬† yes you can parry, but it's like a 1 frame window. I'm lucky enough to get em about 30% of the time, but that's come with a ton of practice
author: @nuttybuddy7928

text: ¬†@nuttybuddy7928¬† Not only that but you have to do it like twice or else they still get you after you parry on the first flash.
author: @Barret9559

text: She was excited for her date and engagement to Shion. She didn't even sleep between this stream and that one.
author: @Leotheleprachaun

text:
Does it even have a better processor? Just the screen with a dedicated ethernet port, no?

Yeah, looking at the Nintendo homepage, there's no mention of core or ram upgrades to the OLED switch. It would just provide a more vibrant color display with better audio.
author: @googletarded8300

text: It's Gura's capture card. Watch Digitalfoundry video, Metroid dread is 60 fps all the way but the cutscenes are 30 fps. The capture card halves the fps tho.
author: @zackmhuntr25

text:
¬†@zackmhuntr25¬† It's not, you can see it going back up to 60 fps on the map at 1:13:45, and you can see the frame rate change at 1:28:45
Capture card wouldn't fluctuate FPS based on what the Switch is rendering
author: @_exilon_

text: but given how much trouble she has with her old capture card, she should still get a high powered PCIe capture card instead so avoid that whole mess
author: @_exilon_

text:
¬†@_exilon_¬† 
Yeah, the switch is a cooling nightmare of thermal grease. I'm on my second one after the first one bricked.
author: @googletarded8300

text: What, do you work for Nintendo?
author: @Disc0_Hipp0

text:
¬†@Disc0_Hipp0¬† 
I see the "your switch seems to have trouble hitting 60fps" followed with "you should buy the OLED model", and can't help but wonder if we even know it will address that problem. Considering Nintendo doesn't seem to claim it does suggests that wouldn't solve her performance problem.

As far as Nintendo throwing globs of cheap thermal grease in the base switch console, I've cleaned mine out and used a combo of thermal paste and thermal pads as an alternative. Using a pair of eyes to look for stuttering, one doesn't need to work at Nintendo to know this cooling is more effective. If people want to make uninformed purchasing decisions regardless of that, that's on them and what they can afford.
author: @googletarded8300
